body:
my instinct from a quick view of oc5 is that the new small icons is a big improvement in use of space.

the question then is whether to fold out the top bar or the left bar.  throwing a thought into the mix, what about killing the *top* bar, compacting the logo and making the icon under the logo be a search button which when clicked unfolds a search box? 

or what about the above, but making the choice of top/left being dependent on screen orientation? laptops are typically increasingly letterbox shaped, so nav on the left makes most sense. tables are tall, so nav on the top.  iphones are tiny, so nav is hidden and unfolder as per "twitter bootstrap".  what do you think? with the new square icons the top or the left seem interchangeable, only the search icon needs horizontal space?


my thought on search is that the globalness is what makes it special?  use osx spotlight as your guide, it's global all the time.  however, some apps (eg email, finder) can have their own subsearch/filter.  i think this fits with most of the default apps already - eg contacts can fit a filter/search above the group list, calendar possibly doesn't make sense to have a search, but it could fit on the top line next to the "configure" icon.  music is perhaps the main default app which needs a search/filter and again perhaps that top nav bar in the app is where it would go (sense a trend here?)

finally: can't see the point of an image of the user? i see my own picture in facebook, but generally i know what *i* look like, not sure i want to see myself, except here it helps, eg "who am i logged in as", or highlighting that i'm in the settings section, ie it's about "me".


please test the design thoughts on a few embedded apps. these are where the pedal hits the metal for integrating with third parties (without having to re-invent every wheel). definitely moving to a narrow ribbon interface, either all top or all left, helps massively!

very thoughtful design for oc6 - congrats

actually, as i wrote on your apps design page.  this ui idea *could* be used for the user page, the contact page, the apps page and on inspection a variant could also be used on the music page! (for music, make a grouping and filter on the left column, music in the right column and one of those columns would then need to be divided to create the play list (but the basic layout would be the same))

like it!

@jancborchardt i would say not the straight away display the apps in the top-bar but have a drop-down instead ( makes it really really clean ). the drop-down doesn't display the apps as a list, with each row displaying an app but as an icon with its name displayed on it's bottom, say, a 4 row x 5 column matrix (ie display space for 20 apps, say). i guess a user wouldn't be using more than this, for an extreme case more apps. can be added to display an entire page of apps enabled. to save a bit more space, you can consider showing the name besides the user image the way it is followed on quora / twitter or even facebook. this is for giving more emphasis to the name than the user image as the user chooses a display name in personal settings too. now, hovering / clicking on the name displays the user settings as of now. how about this way of doing it? i am more than happy to prepare a few mockups if i am being a difficult to understand here :) cc @raydiation @karlitschek @deepdiver1975

i'm not a fan of the idea to put the apps in the top bar as you know. :-) 
this would make the interface very crowded and it doesn't work at all with smaller screens and if you have several 3rd party apps. scrolling is only a bad workaround here.
but most important i don't see the point in changing this again. the users seems to like the current layout so no need to change it again. if we have time to invest in the general layout then we should work on more pressing issues like the non existing mobile interface or a responsive layout or even a small ui framework for common userinterface elements so that 3rd party apps have less work and look better by default.

@karlitschek agree. i like that the apps are on the left side.

if this turns out to be a huge downside later on, we can copy gnome shell or unity like dash.

guys, please remember to evaluate your thoughts on a range of devices (and range of user skill levels).
- personally i prefer apps on the left *on my laptop*, because it's a very letterbox shaped screen
- personally i prefer tabs on the top of the screen on the ipad because i hold it in letter format and scroll. also witness that this is a common layout for many modern, high profile websites, ie tabs at the top (scroll to the top of this page to see that...)
- personally i think that a phone screen is tiny for web pages and hence needs some special thought and compromise or you need to zoom and pinch and drag and ...  so, here some kind of hidden until needed seems sensible
- basically there doesn't seem to be one perfect option, hence consider something dynamic on screen size
- (also name one other high profile website where the "tabs" are on the left rather than the top... consistency...)

with regards to drop down apps list.  personally i think that only the geeky 50% of users will ever find this button.  assuming that the target market is a broad range of users, and the site is viewed as a "web page", rather than an application, then most users (not you and i) will struggle to 
- find anything which won't fit on a 1280x800 screen and needs to be scrolled to
- find anything which drops down or needs clicking on a link smaller than a thumbnail icon
- find major interface cues that are more complex than: a simple list which can be scanned in the classic f shaped scan

now, don't get me wrong, for *me* you could load the interface up with clever drop down clickables and my laptop is set to autohide the dock, etc - *i* like a power user interface.  however, i have to respect that every day i take tech support calls from our users in $job where it takes an average of 1-2 minutes to guide them through opening up our website and *scrolling* slightly down to click a link just off the visible area... real users absolutely struggle to hit dropdown menus accurately and i would say only 70% success rate to hit the drop down item first time...

so, please try to think outside of just the geeks (like us) who are skilled users with a mouse and have the energy to "work out" a new interface.  the average user needs the interface to have some similarity to other common websites that they use daily (which increasingly means tabs at the top, navigation down the left/right, some use of single row dropdowns ok, but try to avoid)

cheers

before this gets a really long threads with lots of opinions and some comparisons which partly do not fit, be assured that i thought about this very long as well.

tl;dr:
